comments.body:
If you do this with a `.foldLeft`, you can do it on a `Set` (or any `Traversable`), which gets rid of a conversion.

Something like this should work.

```scala
      submitters.foldLeft(Right(StepContinue(transactionEntry))) {
        case Left(rejection) =>
          rejection
        case Right(result) =>
          authorize(submitter) match {
            case Some(rejection) => Left(rejection)
            case None => Right(result)
          }
      }
```

You can probably also do this with Scalaz's `traverse`.

As far as I understand the `.foldLeft` approach doesn't allow to fail-fast - I've use recursion specifically for that.
Should I change this?
True, it will still traverse the whole thing. That's where `traverse` would be better. Probably overkill to bring in another dependency though.
Leaving as it is then ðŸ‘
This `catch` needs a test case, which will be done separately to avoid blocking the release further.

I think we should be more careful with the rejection reason. `Disputed` is meant to indicate a bug or malicious behaviour on the participant side. As you explained in the PR comment, we can also end up here if there's a contention issue on contract keys, which should be reported as `Inconsistent`; see `rejectionReasonForValidationError` below.

AFAICS only differences in contract key lookup should get us here with `Inconsistent`. So we could avoid the problem by checking in `validateContractKeys` that the contract keys of the input state resolve to the same contract IDs as those given in the input contracts.
Agreed. Spoke to @gerolf-da and we'll do this separately, as this is blocking the DAML SDK 1.8.0 RC release.

We will address this in two ways during contract key validation:

1. Check that the contract ID is in the declared inputs.
2. Check that contract is actually visible to the submitter.

If either of these fail, we'll reject with `Inconsistent`.

@andreaslochbihler-da, can you confirm this is what we agreed upon?
Sounds good.
This rename just removes an annoying IntelliJ Idea warning about mutators without parentheses.
You can probably configure the IntelliJ inspections to make sure it's not raised.
True but I'd rather people didn't bump into this annoyance, rather than adding an IDE-specific comment or having everyone configure it.
Can you give a bit of color as why we no longer need to check for visibility?
This is quite subtle and articulated and it has to do with the (limited) power of this check and with the evolution of privacy. I recommend to refer to design comments.

When we wrote the multi-party submission design document, we realized that the ledger should not have done the visibility check in the first place.

Note for example that post-commit validation in sandbox classic (e.g., `ActiveLedgerState.lookupContractLet`) doesn't do visibility checks either.
I see, thanks. ðŸ™‡ðŸ»

comments.body: I don't have any context (and the new `CommitContext.minimumRecordTime` property doesn't seem to be used anywhere) - what exactly is the minimum record time, and why does it depend on the submission time and the command deduplication time window?

This property will be read by `KeyValueCommitting.dryRun` for pre-execution (see #6592 ). In case of pre-execution we are delaying the time-bound checks to post-execution as the record time will be only known then. Hence, we have to keep track of the time-bounds that are influenced by submission time and command deduplication time window in case of transactions. In the post-execution phase we only check the current record time against the time-bounds determined by the `Commiter`s.
The time model only describes a relation between the ledger time and the record time, the use of submission time here looks suspicious.

As explained above, for pre-execution we need to ensure that the submission is still valid at the record time determined at post-execution hence the use of submission time here (we verify submission time against record time normally as part of the validation steps performed by `TransactionCommitter` in case of normal execution).

Ok, I see - the validity of submission time is somewhat loosly defined by https://github.com/digital-asset/daml/blob/master/daml-lf/spec/contract-id.rst#submission-time, and you chose to use the ledger time model bounds for submission time check.
Exactly!
